newsitem.title: USA: NHL ICE HOCKEY-LIGHTNING MAKE IT FOUR IN A ROW WITH WIN OVER ISLANDERS.
newsitem.headline: NHL ICE HOCKEY-LIGHTNING MAKE IT FOUR IN A ROW WITH WIN OVER ISLANDERS.

text.p: The surprising Tampa Bay Lightning made it four wins in a row Tuesday and are are off to the best start in the club's five-year history.
John Cullen had a goal and three assists as the Lightning erupted for four first-period goals to down the New York Islanders 6-3 and raise their record to 5-1-0.
Alexander Selivanov, Patrick Poulin, Dino Ciccarelli and Cullen scored in the first period and Brian Bradley added two goals and an assist for Tampa Bay.
Corey Schwab, pressed into a starting role with Daren Puppa out with a groin injury, needed to make just 13 saves.
Zigmund Palffy scored twice for the Isles, losers of three in a row. New York (1-4-1) has only 16 goals in seven games.

Tampa Bay wasted little time in getting to goaltender Eric Fichaud as Selivanov swept a backhander past him 53 seconds into the game. Just 99 seconds later, Poulin's made it 2-0, firing home a one-timer off a pass from Cullen.

After Palffy cut the deficit in half, Cullen picked up the 500th point of his career, deflecting a pass from Poulin past Fichaud. Ciccarelli stuffed in a rebound of a Cullen shot for his fifth goal of the season and a 4-1 lead.
"The first 10 minutes we played like a machine, then we fooled around a bit and gave up some soft goals," said Lightning coach Terry Crisp.

In Philadelphia, Ron Hextall needed to make just 12 saves to record his 15th career shutout and Eric Desjardins had a goal and an assist as the Flyers blanked the Mighty Ducks of Anaheim 3-0 for their third straight win.
Hextall was barely tested, stopping just one shot in the first period and four in the second. The 12 shots allowed by Philadelphia set a franchise low.
Desjardins set up Shjon Podein's goal 8:16 into the game and beat Guy Hebert on a power play 4:14 into the third. Rob Brind'Amour scored with a minute left in the second.
Both teams were missing their top players. Philadelphia's Eric Lindros and Anaheim's Paul Kariya are nursing severe groin injuries and have sat out all season.
In Calgary, Theoren Fleury completed his 11th career hat trick with a goal on a penalty shot as the Flames shocked the Colorado Avalanche 5-1.
Trevor Kidd came within 2:04 of a shutout, making 24 saves before Adam Deadmarsh snapped a rebound of his own shot between Kidd's pads to foil the shutout bid.

Fleury scored in the first and second periods as Calgary built a 3-0 lead. With the Flames up 4-0 late in the game, Fleury was on a breakaway and was pulled down from behind by Peter Forsberg. He beat Patrick Roy low on the glove side on the penalty shot.
In Toronto, Mats Sundin had two goals and an assist as the Maple Leafs ended a five-game losing streak with a 4-3 victory over the San Jose Sharks.
The Maple Leafs won for the first time since opening the season with a victory over Anaheim.
Sundin opened the scoring with his fourth goal 96 seconds into the game and added number five at 18:53 of the third for a 4-2 lead.
Sundin also set up Larry Murphy for a first-period powerplay tally. Doug Gilmour scored the other goal for Toronto, which never trailed.
In Edmonton, Ryan Smyth scored twice as the Oilers produced five unanswered goals in a 5-2 win over the struggling Pittsburgh Penguins.
Mario Lemieux notched his fifth goal midway through the second to put Pittsburgh up 2-0. But Oilers goaltender Curtis Joseph stopped 34 shots, including all 12 in the final period.

Jason Arnott, forced to miss several shifts after crashing heavily into the end boards early in the third, came back to snap a 2-2 tie at 8:37 as the Oilers victimised Ken Wregget five times over the last two periods.
Smyth, who picked up his sixth and seventh goals, and Andrei Kovalenko later beat Wregget 37 seconds apart.
In Phoenix, Jim Campbell scored with 13:26 left in the third period to snap a tie and Grant Fuhr made 26 saves to lift the St Louis Blues to a 2-1 victory over the Coyotes.
Geoff Courtnall took a pass at centre ice, crossed the blue line and passed to a streaking Campbell, who tipped it past goaltender Nikolai Khabibulin from the left doorstep for the game winner.
Norm Maciver's second-period goal had put Phoenix in front. But Brett Hull tied the game for St Louis with just 10 seconds left in the period, deflecting a Courtnall slap shot into the Phoenix goal.
